title: Trichuriasis
parasite_biology:
### Causal Agent

The nematode (roundworm) _Trichuris trichiura_ , also called the human
whipworm.

### Life Cycle

![lifecycle](/dpdx/trichuriasis/modules/Trichuris_LifeCycle.gif?_=01176)

The unembryonated eggs are passed with the stool ![The number
1](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_1.gif). In the
soil, the eggs develop into a 2-cell stage ![The number
2](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_2.gif), an
advanced cleavage stage ![The number
3](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_3.gif), and then
they embryonate ![The number
4](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/generic_4.gif); eggs
become infective in 15 to 30 days. After ingestion (soil-contaminated hands or
food), the eggs hatch in the small intestine, and release larvae ![The number
5](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/small_intestine_5.gif)
that mature and establish themselves as adults in the colon ![The number
6](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/images/life_cycle_numbers/large_intestine_6.gif).
The adult worms (approximately 4 cm in length) live in the cecum and ascending
colon. The adult worms are fixed in that location, with the anterior portions
threaded into the mucosa. The females begin to oviposit 60 to 70 days after
infection. Female worms in the cecum shed between 3,000 and 20,000 eggs per
day. The life span of the adults is about 1 year.

### Geographic Distribution

The third most common round worm of humans. Worldwide, with infections more
frequent in areas with tropical weather and poor sanitation practices, and
among children. It is estimated that 800 million people are infected
worldwide. Trichuriasis occurs in the southern United States.

### Clinical Presentation

Most frequently asymptomatic. Heavy infections, especially in small children,
can cause gastrointestinal problems (abdominal pain, diarrhea, rectal
prolapse) and possibly growth retardation.

#####  _T. trichiura_ eggs.

_Trichuris trichiura_ eggs are 50-55 micrometers by 20-25 micrometers. They
are barrel-shaped, thick-shelled and possess a pair of polar “plugs” at each
end. The eggs are unembryonated when passed in stool.

#####  _T. trichiura_ adults.

Adult males of _Trichuris trichiura_ are 30-45 millimeters long, with a coiled
posterior end. Adult females are 35-50 millimeters with a straight posterior
end. Both sexes have a long, whip-like anterior end. Adults reside in the
large intestine, cecum and appendix of the host.

![](/dpdx/trichuriasis/images/4/Trichuris_trichiura_adult_Duke.jpg?_=01185)

Figure A: Posterior end of an adult _T. trichiura_ , taken during a
colonoscopy. Image courtesy of Duke University Medical Center.

![](/dpdx/trichuriasis/images/4/T_trichiura_adult_HB1.jpg?_=01182)

Figure B: Adult if _T. trichiura_ removed during a colonoscopy.

![](/dpdx/trichuriasis/images/4/T_trichiura_adult_HB2.jpg?_=01183)

Figure C: Higher magnification of the anterior end of the specimen in Figure
B.

![](/dpdx/trichuriasis/images/4/T_trichiura_adult_HB3.jpg?_=01187)

Figure D: Higher magnification of the posterior end of the specimen in Figure
B. Notice the prominent spicule.
lab_diagnosis:
### Laboratory Diagnosis

Microscopic identification of whipworm eggs in feces is evidence of infection.
Because eggs may be difficult to find in light infections, a concentration
procedure is recommended. Because the severity of symptoms depend on the worm
burden, quantification of the latter (e.g. with the Kato-Katz technique) can
prove useful.

Examination of the rectal mucosa by proctoscopy (or directly in case of
prolapses) can occasionally demonstrate adult worms.

[Morphologic comparison with other intestinal
parasites](https://www.cdc.gov/dpdx/diagnosticProcedures/stool/morphcomp.html)
